message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has CF, which makes him susceptible to infections like Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Inhaled tobramycin is the best treatment option for this patient as it specifically targets Pseudomonas aeruginosa in the lungs. Dornase alfa helps thin the mucus and decrease inflammation but would not treat the infection. Oral cephalexin and minocycline are not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient with CF has a respiratory infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa and the best treatment option is inhaled tobramycin for 28 days, which is effective against Pseudomonas. Dornase alfa is used to break up mucus in the airways but is not effective against infections. Oral antibiotics such as cephalexin and minocycline may not be effective against Pseudomonas and may also have side effects such as gastrointestinal disturbances and photosensitivity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and sputum culture reveal Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a common bacteria in CF patients. Inhaled tobramycin is commonly used to treat chronic Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections in CF patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common pathogen in patients with CF and is often treated with inhaled tobramycin. Dornase alfa is an enzyme used to break up thick mucus in the lungs, but it is not effective against bacteria. Oral cephalexin and minocycline are antibiotics, but they may not be effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms indicate an exacerbation of CF, and the sputum culture revealing Pseudomonas aeruginosa suggests an infectious cause. Inhaled tobramycin is an antibiotic commonly used for treatment of Pseudomonas infections in patients with CF. Dornase alfa is used to decrease viscosity of secretions in CF, but it is not the best option for an acute exacerbation. Oral antibiotics like cephalexin and minocycline are not sufficient for treating Pseudomonas infections in CF.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has clinical and laboratory evidence of a pulmonary exacerbation of CF, with Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection. Inhaled tobramycin is an appropriate treatment option for CF patients that have a positive culture for Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Dornase alfa is used to reduce mucus viscosity, cephalexin and minocycline are not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has CF with Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection, and the treatment of choice is inhaled tobramycin. Dornase alfa is used to thin mucus in CF patients, cephalexin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic not typically used for Pseudomonas infections, and minocycline is not the first-line treatment for CF infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the sputum cultures suggest a worsening of the patient's CF. Inhaled tobramycin has been shown to be effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and is a standard treatment option for exacerbations in CF patients. Dornase alfa helps improve lung function but is not indicated for treating infections. Oral cephalexin has limited activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Minocycline is not a recommended antibiotic for CF infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s elevated temperature, increased sputum production and cough, and positive sputum culture for Pseudomonas aeruginosa suggests an acute exacerbation of CF. Inhaled tobramycin is the best treatment option for this patient, as it is an antibiotic effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and is often used in CF patients for exacerbations. Dornase alfa helps reduce airway inflammation but is not effective against bacterial infections. Oral cephalexin and minocycline are not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has CF, which predisposes him to recurrent infections with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The most effective treatment for this is inhaled tobramycin, which has been shown to improve pulmonary function and decrease sputum bacterial density in CF patients with chronic Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Option B, Dornase alfa, helps break down DNA in sputum but is not effective against the bacteria. Option C, oral cephalexin, is not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa in the lungs. Option D, minocycline, is not typically used to treat CF-related infections.
